--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "Mattias Fagerlund" <mattias@c...> wrote:
> > Here's how he picks the initial inputs:  In the initial
population,
> > for each member of the population, each input has a 1/(number of
> > inputs) chance of being connected. 
> 
> And if it's picked to be connected, then it's fully connected - as
per 
> original NEAT? Sounds fair enough.
> 

Right, if an input is picked to be connected, it is fully-connected
to the outputs.

> > Also the bias is always connected
> > to the outputs.  So on average each network has the bias and one
other
> > input connected.  Any network with only the bias connected is
forced
> > to have one other connection connected.  So the initial
population is
> > minimal but diverse.
> 
> OK
>  
> > Here's another thing Shimon suggested:  Instead of training one
big
> > OCR network, train a separate network for each letter.  And do the
> > training separately, i.e. an "is it a 'b'?" network and a
separate "is
> > it an 'a'?" network.
> 
> Intereting - it would cut down the size of the networks
significantly - 
> even fully connected networks would be feasable - even though I like
the 
> ideas of starting minimally.
> 
> However, this wouldn't work with my current demo, because it only
inputs 
> one image of each letter. I'd have to add alternative letters,
either 
> damaged "a":s or "a":s from other fonts.
> 

Well, you could lete ach network see all your letters, and just rate
them on their ability to fire only for the appropriate one.

> Interestingly enough, it would be trivial to merge 26 such networks
into 
> a single network that solves all letters at once - why you would
want to 
> do that is unclear...
> 

It might be interesting to merge it into one network and then keep
training with lots of noisy examples.  Maybe NEAT would find
connections among the different subnetworks that are helpful.

ken
